Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the mother needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Story:
I stood in the corner of the crowded room, swirling my drink, trying to focus on the laughter and chatter around me. My mind kept drifting back to the looming home loan repayment. Two months. I needed to make sure we had enough, and every decision I made at work felt heavier, knowing my family’s stability depended on it. As a mother, I felt the weight of that responsibility pressing on my chest.

A colleague approached, smiling, and asked about one of my high-profile cases. “Just between us,” she said, “what’s really going on with your client?” The question was casual, but I felt my stomach twist. As a lawyer, I was bound by confidentiality and ethics—no matter how much I wanted to fit in, to maybe secure a referral or a new client that could help with our finances. The expectations of my profession clashed with the desperate need to provide for my family. I could feel the tension rising inside me, torn between the urge to protect my client’s trust and the silent plea to do whatever it took for my family’s future.
